On May 28, Mr. Nelson wrote to Dick Hull to reply for both the
Fund for the Advancement of Education and the Ford Foundation.
After reminding us that he had made no promises during our meeting
of May 21, he then said that it would be impossible for either Fund
or Foundation to support the project we had presented to them.
Why this flat and complete turndown for our big proposal? All
four of us were optimistic after our talk with Mr, Nelson. However,
for the record X should report that he did indeed tell us that he
did not have the authority to commit either Fund or Foundation.
Furthermore, he did not say anything which specifically declared
his approval, although we felt (perhaps wishfully!) that his line
of questioning implied approval. But he warned uss the decision
would depend not only upon the merits of our case, but also upon
the general earning status of the Ford Motor Company, as well as
on the overall policies of the Fund and Foundation in regard to
broadcasting.
What do we do now? Dick, as Foundation Committee chairman,
is exploring the possibility of a grant for a smaller project.
While the action of the Fund and Foundation appears to be final
on our big proposal, the door may still be open for a terminal
grant providing for a gradual tapering down of our present Ford-
supported activities.
As things develop, 1*11 keep you informed.
(3) The Magnuson Bill
The Senate passed the Magnuson Bill on May 29. The final
text of the bill, together with the discussion which preceded its
passage, may be found in the Congressional Record, Senate, for May
29, pp. 8779-8782. Congratulations to our committee (headed by
Bob Schenkkan) for its good work! We are already in touch with
Lenny Marks about the bill*s future in the House.
(4) Board of Directors Meeting Plans
It was the unanimous feeling of the executive committee after
the Washington meeting that its results taken alone do not require
a meeting of the Board of Directors. At some past general meetings,
informal off-the-record conferences among the representatives of
the major groups present have lead to long-range plans. In this
case, though, the representatives of the JCET, the ETRC and the
founcations were not of policy forming level. However, the stateÂ¬
ment of conclusions which Dick Hull is now formulating may provide
us with guidance for future NAEB activities. But it was our feeling
that nothing growing out of this conference would justify the
trouble and the expense of an immediate Board meeting.
As to a meeting to discuss Foundation relations, it is too
early to tell if such a session is required. This will depend on
what develops as a result of Dick*s further negotiations with the
Ford and Fund people.
